subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Homologizing Language
msgSnippet: Welcome to the group.  Although I have not studied the history of English spelling per se, it appears to me that we got into this mess due to the wide
messageBody:
Welcome to the group.  Although I have not studied the history of English spelling per se, it appears to me that we got into this mess due to the wide distribution of English speakers around the world, the insistence on spelling standardization and the lack of any mechanism that could enforce updated spelling changes to keep the written language in sync with the spoken tongue.  It is my understanding that some countries, such as Germany, do have such a mechanism, and about every 50 years or so, they update standard spellings to bring them back in line with current pronunciations.  I can’t see any way this could be done with English. 

 

Your prediction that one dialect in English may win out over others due to the impact of the media does not seem particularly likely to me.  I can listen to Peter Jennings for years, but that has not affected my own idiolect as far as I can tell.

 

Paige Gabhart

 

"I despise a world which does not feel that music is a higher revelation than all wisdom and philosophy."
-Ludwig van Beethoven

 

-----Original Message-----
From: acolyteofmaille [mailto:acolyteofmaille@...]
Sent: Tuesday, January 25, 2005 8:35 PM
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Homologizing Language


Hello! I'm new to QS, I'm still learning to read it fluently (I've
started taking notes from my book with it though, it's not TOO slow
for the time I have)

I couldn't find anything about any of this, forgive me if it's all bee
said and debated before.

One of the reasons QS was made was to get rid of the problems in
standardized spelling. If QS actually does succeed as the standard
(good luck!) Merrian-Webster and every other dictionary maker will
print dictionaries in QS (or have the word in QS and the def. in
Roman.) People will likely do the same thing with that as they do with
the Roman alphabet. Desire for set structure and order is basic part
of human nature. It is shown in all religion, from the Celtic to
Christianaty and is obviously manifest in the city based society
today. Standardized spelling has been instutionalized as one more
thing to keep in order, and it is very likely that it will be passed
from parents and teachers to children. The simplicity and speed of QS
are probably the only benefits it will hold if it ever becomes widely
used.
Even if that doesn't happen (maybey especially) one dialect may
eventually become the predominant one by the wide circulation of media
from it. If people start speaking the way they read, which is quite
possible through the whole sub-vocalization process that people do
when reading, then what they read the most may change their own
speech, and in turn change their friends' speech, etc. (Was that
apostraphe right? Stupid bloody possesive plurals...) making, most
likely, the western US accent go almost worldwide. Of course New York
will never change because they still haven't despite the attempts
we've made to fix th I mean the amount of television with our accent
that they have been exposed to, but that is, of course, fine (whew,
that was a close save...) The main British accent may also win out,
there are quite a few books coming to the US from there. More likely
is a mixture, especially since the main TV ones are about the same (if
that guy that NPR rebrodcasts from the BBC is representative of the
majority of Britan.)
So what do you all think about that hypothesis? It would solve the
copy-cat spelling problem, because we'd all talk the same anyway so
phonetics would work fine in all cases. (Almost.)
But that would take years and years (or decades and decades of
decadence... sorry, I just had to do that for the parrallelism) so the
dictionary spelling will more likely take back over.

And this has likely been discussed, but what can actually be done to
prevent the spelling problems? I suppose a lot of that can be how it
is presented: spelling doesn't matter, it is made to be flexible. I
think that needs to be emphasized.
